results.title: The Vatican
results.brief_description:

An interesting tour of Vatican City showing its buildings, art treasures, security guards and its residents.

results.title: John Constable
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Constable’s greatness lies in his love of nature and his urge to express this love as directly as possible through a faithful transcription of its moods. Written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems

results.title: Jean-Auguste Dominique Ingres. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Ingres was a pure artist, a believer in art for art’s sake. Like Degas, he was obsessed with an ideal of perfect form to which he gave his whole life, but succeeded in capturing it only when the subject was the female nude. Narrated by Kenneth Clark.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems

results.title: Jean-Auguste Dominique Ingres. No. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Examines Ingres’ reputation as the archetypal Classic artist and finds it misleading. Ingres escaped completely from orthodox classicism by making direct studies of Greek vases rather than by copying established interpreters. Narrated by Kenneth Clark.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems

results.title: Jean Francois Millet
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Discusses the works of Jean Francois Millet, whose subjects were intensely Romantic, but whose treatment of the human figure was entirely Classical. His early work is almost a total negation of his later achievement.

results.title: Jacques-Louis David (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Looks at some famous works of the French artist, Jacques-Louis David, which bear all the strengths and weaknesses of Classicism. Narrated by Kenneth Clark.

results.title: J.M. Turner. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark and John Brabourne Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Deals with Turner’s rediscovery of colour and its direct appeal to the senses, regardless of subject matter. He is considered by many to be the first “abstract” artist. One of the series of films written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark on the painters and sculptors who from 1750 to 100 engaged in the struggle between the classic and romantic ideals.

results.title: J.M. Turner. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark and John Brabourne Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Reviews the neglected works of Turner, concentrating on alpine scenes which show how he completely understood nature. One of the series of films written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark on the painters and sculptors who from 1750 to 1900 engaged in the struggle between the classic and romantic ideals.

results.title: Francisco Goya (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions, Sotheby's, Visual Programme Systems and W. H. Smith
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
This film traces the disturbing story of Goya’s career, the changes in which were apparent in his work. His early work depicted light hearted scenes. As a court painter he was one of the most sought after portrait painters in Madrid. After he became deaf he embarked on a series of etchings depicting a world of deformed bodies. Written and narrated by Kenneth Clark.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions, Sotheby’s, Visual Programme Systems and W. H. Smith
